Reviews.Author: Jason Dude
Reviews.Content: I have the first Kindle Fire that I still use and love. I just received the new Fire 8.9 which I ordered without advertisements. At first glance it is just bigger and heavier. But it has more storage, has a better screen, Bluetooth and a cool mosaic photo display when in landscape position. Yes, I have read the specs and know there is more under the hood but I don't care as long as it works well. I do like the layout of the new carousel and favorites better. I also like that it is harder to move the icons around in favorites. I like to put them in my own order but on the first Fire they would randomly skip across the screen by accident. One big OOOPPPS Amazon made is with the new case. If you are watching a video and you have the cover opened to support the Fire in the landscape position you cannot leave it plugged in. I am sure other companies will get on that soon. I do love the magnetic cover that turns the Fire on and off. I was horrified that there was no 'FLASH' because I watch several video podcasts that are still in flash. However, there is a flash work around. Go to your account, help, forums on the right and type in flash for Fire 8.9. There is a nice lady that has that all organized for you. You basically download a free app (ES File Explorer)  then download an old version of Dolphin Browser to the app and then the flash for Dolphin. It works perfect. Today as I watched my flash video podcast I was amazed at how good the video is on the new HD screen. Also, I actually think my music sounds better on the Fires so I take one to the gym instead of my iPod. I use AblePlanet noise cancelling headphones and ear buds and both are really really good. Good luck with your new toy.April 2013 Update - I loved this Kindle Fire but sadly in December it died on me and I had to return it. I hope to get another one soon.
Reviews.Title: Gorgeous Screen, Better Sound & Flash Work Around

Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: I have had my fire hd for over a week now and i love it.  I`ve also had a kindle keyboard and original kindle fire.  Was not sure about purchasing the fire hd 8.9 at first but decided i wanted to try the larger screen so i pre-ordered it.  I never did use the kindle fire one handed so the larger size of the fire hd doesn`t bother me.  I love the hd screen and larger size.  Fire hd feels very well constructed.  I found it very easy to use but that may be because i had the kindle fire and so was not a first time user.  It should still prove easy to use for someone who is new to kindle fire.  Fire hd is very fast for surfing the web and watching prime instant videos.  Display is incredible with hd content and sound is good for a tablet.  I really like having the hdmi out port so i can connect it to my home theater.  Some have complained about no charging light like the original fire so you can`t tell when it`s fully charged but while that is an annoyance it`s not enough for me to ding the fire hd in my review.  Be careful how much trust you place in the overly negative reviews.  A lot of them seem to have been written by, a - apple fan boys who feel threatened and so surf the internet writing negative reviews of competing products, b - people with unreasonable expectations i.e. did not fully read product description before purchasing, and lastly, c - people who are not reviewing the fire hd at all but are leaving negative reviews because they have a bone to pick with amazon.  Lastly, just a thought about the lack of apps complaints.  Amazon is a merchant not a developer, it is up to the developers to make sure their apps work with the fire hd.
Reviews.Title: kindle fire hd 8.9

Reviews.Author: Paul S. Remington
Reviews.Content: This review discusses whether or not to buy a Kindle in place of a different platform, such as an iPad.  It also discusses the pros and cons related to purchasing a new 8.9" HD Kindle Fire as an upgrade to the old Kindle Fire.Maybe you're one of those who would like a tablet, but aren't entirely sure which one to buy.  Should you get an iPad, a NOOK, a Kindle, or some other tablet?  It's a big decision.  In the end, there is not one right decision, just the decision that is right for you.  Only you can make that decision, so I'll tell you our experience and you can compare that to how you think it might fit into your decision.Right now you're considering a Kindle from Amazon, and I won't say you're making a wrong choice.  The advantage of the Kindle is its price and how well it integrates Amazon content.  Being an Android-based device, there is an enormous amount of app support.  Not as much as Apple supports, but for most people, there's enough support to satisfy what you want to do.My wife has an iPad and I have a Kindle.  She loves her iPad, but she admits that there's nothing that she does on her Apple that she can't do on the Kindle.  Most everything she does on her iPad, she can also do on my Kindle.  She chose the iPad because her niece and sister have one and she wanted a similar device so she can map her apps in line with theirs.  I support her reasoning and it makes total sense.  She's Chinese and has language-specific apps she uses.  So, when making your decision, write down everything you feel you would like to do with the tablet, then research what native programs and downloadable apps there are that will enable you to do what you want on the tablet's platform (Android, Apple, etc.).  The Kindle is a lot cheaper than the iPad.  This is a major selling point some use to justify their choice of one platform over the other.For me, the Kindle is a more logical platform.  I love Amazon content and am an Amazon Prime member.  I have over 40 CDs I've purchased on Amazon and they all reside on the cloud (server-side storage my Kindle accesses wirelessly).  I've purchased a small library of books and love to browse their massive arsenal of products.  I feel like the Kindle was made for me.If you're like me and have already purchased a Kindle Fire and are considering upgrading to the new 8.9" HD Kindle Fire, I can tell you it's a nice upgrade, but it's not perfect.So here's my list of cons for the new HD Kindle Fire.The Web browser on the 8.9" HD Kindle, called Silk, doesn't support Flash.  The iPad also doesn't support Flash.  Some will tell you that you can't use Flash on the new HD Kindle Fire.  This is not true.  You have to install a different Web browser and do a few configuration steps to get Flash installed and working.  If you research this on the Web, you can locate instructions on how to do this.The old Kindle Fire came with a wall charger; the new HD Kindle Fire doesn't.  Charging is done very slowly using a USB cable connected to another device.  You can purchase a fast charger, but this is an extra purchase.  If you have the charger from your old Kindle Fire, you can use that also, and it'll charge much faster than the USB charger.  In fact, that old charger will charge as fast as the new "fast" charger for the HD Kindle Fire (sold separately).  If you're upgrading, you might want to save your money and just use your old charger.The old Kindle Fire had an LED on the power button that turned green when the Kindle was fully charged and Amber when it was still charging.  The new HD Kindle Fire doesn't have any LED, so you don't know the true state of the battery while it's charging.  There are apps you can purchase to help with this, but out of the box, the new HD Kindle Fire is not as convenient in this regard.I've had a few problems with the HD Kindle Fire not powering up after a charge.  This has happened three times in six weeks.  The first time, I called Amazon and was put through quickly (on a Sunday, I might add) to a technical support representative who instructed me to press and hold the start button for one minute, then let go, then press it again.  This forced a reboot of the device, and when it powered back up, everything worked great.  I was impressed with the rapid and helpful customer support.  I'm not sure what's causing the HD Kindle Fire to occasionally not power up, but the fix is a quick one and it happens rarely.Here is my list of Pros for the new HD Kindle Fire.The audio quality is excellent, for a tablet.  Don't look for any booming bass or ear splitting volume, but compared to the old Kindle Fire, it's a substantial upgrade.  The new HD Kindle Fire has surround sound audio processing that mimics wrapping the sound around you.  It actually works.  Watching movies or listening to music, there's an enhanced stereo effect that is a noticeable upgrade to the old Kindle Fire.The full-HD video quality is nicely enhanced on the new HD Kindle Fire.  If you look very close, you can see the individual pixels, but at a respectable distance, the video quality is much more uniform and smooth, colors are vibrant, and the video quality is richer.Wireless access I've noticed is much better.  I'm able to measure a 10dB to 20dB increase in wireless strength during side-by-side comparisons with my old Kindle Fire.  I've read others state they don't notice a difference, and perhaps that relates to the wireless router they have or where the router is situated, but I notice (and can measure) a difference.  Using the wireless bars on the GUI, my old Kindle Fire always displays three bars in most locations in our home while the new HD Kindle Fire displays four bars.The screen is noticeably larger, which is definitely a nice upgrade when watching movies, browsing the Web, or typing on the screen.  I still prefer the smaller Kindle Fire for book reading.  It's sized more like a paperback, but I do plenty of reading on the 8.9" HD Fire also, so it doesn't detract from my enjoyment.I see a tablet like a tool in someone's tool chest.  Each tool has a specific function and each person needs to find the tool that's right for them.  For my wife, her tool is the iPad.  For me, it's the Kindle.  Which is it for you?
Reviews.Title: Considering whether to upgrade or buy a Kindle?  Perhaps our experience can help you decide.

Reviews.Author: G. Denick
Reviews.Content: I own and have previously used a regular Kindle for reading, which I preferred using over traditional paperbacks. The Fire HD, remarkably, is even BETTER to read from - which came as a surprise to me, since I assumed it would not match the reading experience of the regular Kindle. I find the bright screen of the Fire HD to be marvelous to read from. I experience no glare, and can read for prolonged periods of time with no issues whatsoever. The screen can be read in any lighting condition, since it's so bright. For some people, it will be a tad TOO bright, but I believe you can adjust this in the settings. I'm not quite sure if I like this unit better than my 7" Fire HD, but it's a toss up- they're both stellar. If you're going to use it primarily for reading books, the 7" may be the best fit, but the 9" would probably be better for heavy use of Netflix and/or reading of comics and magazines.What I really love about the Fire HD's reading interface is how it makes me a BETTER reader. How? A number of ways. First of all, I love the feature that lets me highlight passages that I like by simply running my finger over them, making them easy to revisit at a later time. I used to enjoy highlighting passages in traditional books, but I was generally too involved in my book to get up and go look for a pen - so I skipped it. Additionally, one of the Fire's functions conveniently stores all highlighted areas, so you can easily go back to your favorite parts (as well as having a simpler "bookmark" feature). You can even "share" the passages you like on social networks, if you're into that sort of thing. All of these things were possible with the regular Kindle e-reader, but with this tablet, they're 100x easier (thanks to an intuitive, responsive touch interface), and I actually find myself USING the features (all the time).The Fire HD also retains the ability to change the size of the font you're reading, quickly and easily. Again, this is something that the previous Kindle could do, but I find it much more intuitive with the touch controls. Once you get used to the way the device works (which doesn't take long), everything becomes second nature.What else? Page turns are smooth and seamless (something the original Fire stuttered on). Turning pages is incredibly slick - you don't even get that brief "black flash" that the regular Kindle performs to refresh its pixels. In fact, you can even PARTIALLY turn the pages, just like in a real book! You turn pages with a quick swipe of the thumb. But if you keep your thumb on the screen/page, you can gently begin to turn the page forward/backward, and hold it where you want. Very useful, if you quickly want to go back to the last sentence or two you read on the previous page, or peek ahead to see if you're near the end of the chapter.I also find that I love having color in my Kindle. Although reading is primarily a black and white affair, it's great to have color when you're perusing the covers of the books in your library, as well as when you're seeing the occasional picture. I generally read novels, but I've perused comics and picture books, and the Fire HD delivers in stunning fashion.Speaking of that color screen (and it should be mentioned that cramming 720p resolution into a 9" screen is a technological marvel), video is also outstanding (something that I also couldn't do on my previous Kindle). It's really fun to read for a bit in bed, and then catch a quick episode of "Parks and Rec" on the Netflix app. It doesn't look quite as sharp as it does on my 40" 1080p Samsung (understandable), but it looks darned good, and I feel like it might get even better with downloaded movies (as opposed to streaming). I watched a trailer for a Batman movie on the demo unit at Staples, and it was incredible- it's what sealed the deal for me. The sound on the Fire HD is everything it's been hyped to be, coming through crisp and loud. I also like the placement of the speakers, because if you hold the tablet with both hands, it bounces off of your palms and comes right back at you (although you can still hear it just fine, no matter how you hold it).The Fire HD has some faults - the charging time is painfully slow with the included USB charger, the power button is ridiculously hard to find, and the surface of the back is a bit too slippery. But these flaws are easy to overlook, considering all that I get in return from my Fire HD. It truly makes me look forward to reading every night, and it's a lot of fun to build and browse my digital library (I'm currently collecting Newberry Medal winners - and the ease with which I can quickly download these should also be commended). Read on, readers!
Reviews.Title: A reader's perspective (how the Fire HD works for reading books)

Reviews.Author: K. Howard "Kindle Ho"
Reviews.Content: After reading so many asinine 1- and 2-star reviews, I thought I should go ahead and get my review out there.  And before anyone has a chance to question it, though this is not a verified purchase, I DO own this device.  My folks were kind enough to let me purchase this through my Dad's account, and pay him back over time.  But anyhooooo, about the device...The first thing I noticed when I opened the box was how thin the Fire was!  The original Fire, though I absolutely love mine, was rather blocky.  My new baby was charged up, so I turned it on and checked out the picture.  Absolutely freaking beautiful!  Before I really played with it, I plugged it in and charged it up.  No, a charger was not included with it.  But I READ the product description and knew that, so I had already ordered the quick charger, even though I already had other chargers.When it was pretty quickly charged, I got down to some serious playing.  I have to admit that I am totally blown away by the beauty of the picture.  I don't own any other HD devices, so I was not prepared for just how gorgeous the images would be.  I was easily able to explore the Fire, as the quick tutorial explained what was needed to get started.  I loaded a number of books, lots of music and apps, and some pictures.  I am thrilled that this device can be loaded with my personal pictures.  It was extremely easy to do through the cloud.  And they look fantastic!I checked out the sound.  Dang, Green Day and Pink sounded absolutely awesome coming through the Dolby speakers!  No, it doesn't sound like a Bose sound system, but come on....this is a tablet.  I think it sounds fabulous.  Haven't tried it with headphones yet, but I will.I then played on the reading app.  Love it!  Though I do most of my reading on my Kindle Keyboard and Paperwhite, it will be very easy to read on this device.  Everything was crisp and clear...I especially like the sepia background; it's very easy on the eyes.Now we come to the apps.  No, not all of the apps I had on the original Fire would load onto the Fire HD.  Nor did I expect them too.  And I frankly don't care.  If I want to play them, I'll play on the original Fire.  Rooting?  Side loading?  Huh?  Nope, don't even want to attempt that.  I'm very pleased with the content I can get for my device from Amazon.  I bought this tablet for entertainment purposes.  And I know as time goes by, more apps will be adapted to work for the Fire HD.  The 8.9" screen makes such a huge difference when playing apps.  I no longer worry about going blind playing Mahjong on my smaller screen!I then decided to check out some TV episodes I bought.  Copper looks fantastic on the HD screen!  I also checked a Prime movie - X-ray is such an awesome idea.  No more going crazy trying to figure out who is playing a particular role; I just look it up without having to go to the web.  Watching movies is truly a beautiful experience on the Fire HD.  I haven't used HDMI (did I type that correctly?).  I don't have an HD TV.  Besides, I like to watch on my 8.9" screen.My Yahoo and Hotmail e-mail accounts were easily set up.  I like the e-mail app on the Fire HD better than the one on the original Fire.  I went to the browser and put my favorite websites on and bookmarked them.  This device is much faster than the Fire.  I will admit that the browser locked up and reset a few times.  I'm using a stylus, and sometimes I tap more than I should (which I did on the original Fire because I had to).  I'm getting used to the screen, though, and it's happening less as time goes by.  And I have had tabs not respond; but they recover so quickly, it's a total non-issue for me.I believe Amazon Prime is a MUST if you own this device.  Besides the free shipping on millions of items, you WILL want the free Prime TV shows and movies to get the most out of your Fire HD.I highly recommend the Fire HD 8.9" 32GB with no hesitation whatsoever.  I mentioned some of the asinine reviews I read and would like to touch on a few points.  If you read the product description, you will know what this device can and cannot do.  Unless you live under a rock, I don't know how anyone doesn't know that Adobe no longer supports flash and is no longer used on new android devices.  And I can't say I know absolutely for sure what flash is, but I know I don't miss it!  Same goes for the device not coming with a charger; it's not listed in what comes in the box, and it has been discussed here more than once..  Someone said his Fire HD had sharp edges.  Eh?  Still trying to figure that one out!  The edges of mine are very nicely rounded, thank you very much.  There's no forward facing camera!  Call me crazy, but if I want to take pictures, I use a camera (or my cell phone if it's a "photo emergency").  Reviews have downgraded the device because of packaging or delivery times.  Sorry, but what does that have to do with the performance of the device?  There were also the reviews that were not reviews of the Fire HD, but were plugs for their favored Nook or Apple devices.  Then there are the defectivebydesign mindless Zombie reviews.  No comment.  But my favorite bad review was the guy who couldn't stand touchscreen devices.  Then why the heck did you order one that you KNEW was a touchscreen device?!?!?!Get one of these babies for yourself and check it out.  I think you'll love yours as much as I love mine!
Reviews.Title: A review for the non-techies among us

Reviews.Author: Tony Chang
Reviews.Content: I chose to purchase the Kindle Fire HD 8.9" rather than the other competitive tablets for several reasons.1. AMAZON PRIME EXPERIENCE:I have Amazon Prime, and I am a pretty devoted customer. I use Amazon quite often for purchasing goods and for watching movies/shows, so I wanted to take advantage of the Prime experience with Amazon's own Kindle Fire HD product.2. 8.9" PERFECT SCREEN SIZE:It has the perfect screen size. It isn't too small like the 7-inch tablets, and it isn't too big and bulky like the ~10-inch tablets.3. BEAUTIFUL RESOLUTION1920x1200 with 254 PPI. That's almost like IPAD 4's RETINA Display, but almost half the price.4. DUAL SPEAKERS DOLBY SOUND SYSTEM:The only tablet with dual speakers, and with the legendary Dolby.5. PRICEPrice was relatively cheap. Although, competitive tablets are reducing their price to try to compete.After a few days of use, I was able to pin-point the PROs and CONs of the Kindle Fire HD 8.9", or at least my specific Kindle Fire HD 8.9" device.PROS:1. Screen Resolution: Absolutely beautiful2. Sound System: Possibly the best sound system of all tablets. Plus there's an app to boost the volume.3. Amazon Prime Experience: Easy to use to watch Amazon Prime movies/videos and Amazon MP3 Cloud music4. Screen Size: Perfect for me5. Amazon Support: Great customer support to answer  any Kindle Fire HD 8.9" questions or issuesDespite all that, I believe my specific Kindle Fire HD 8.9" was defective. First of all, when my Kindle Fire HD 8.9" was delivered, it was delivered without a box and protective airbags, it just came by itself in the Kindle Fire HD 8.9" black box. I found my Kindle Fire HD 8.9" black box in the dirt in front of my house and it was pretty badly beaten up on the edges and sides. When I opened it everything was there, but my info card/manual was already taken out, but my Kindle was still in the plastic wrap and the USB was still under it.After one day of use, I noticed some bad things about my Kindle Fire HD 8.9". This included:CONS:1. Battery: Device would get REALLY hot after a few minutes of use (After 20 minutes of use playing the Oregon Trail game app, my Kindle's battery was over 118 degrees Fahrenheit according to the Battery app). My device even automatically shut down one time. Also I only get about 6 hours of battery life (instead of the promised over 10 hours) with moderate web surfing ONLY with default 70% brightness.2. SILK Web Browser: Absolutely crap. The SILK browser for my Kindle was really slow, and it lagged my whole device. Swype typing was about 1.33 seconds slower than my finger speed, and pulling the top notification/setting bar down was really blocky. SILK was incompatible with several webpages, and could not finish running any browser tests. On several occasions, SILK automatically closed on me while I was browsing, and I lost the page I was on because it restarted back to SILK's homepage when I reopened it. Also does not have Adobe Flash Player.3. Processor Speed: My processor speed was pretty rubbish. My phone (Atrix HD) runs faster than my Kindle Fire HD 8.9, and my phone isn't even that fast (has same dual core 1.5ghz though). Very blocky and laggy on several apps other than the home screen carousel.4. Carousel: This isn't a defectiveness, but it is a CON. When I download apps that are not from the app store, the app's picture on my carousel is very pixelatedRecommendations and Tips:- Download Dolphin Browser, it works a lot faster and you can get Adobe Flash Player on it. Also better quality everything.- Recommended Apps (not from App Store, google around for it): Dolphin Browser, ES File Explorer, Adobe Flash Player 11, 1Mobile Market gets you YoutubeI have contacted Amazon about my specific Kindle Fire HD 8.9" device and they are sending me a replacement. I will update this review a few days after receiving the replacement.
Reviews.Title: Promising, but mine seemed defective

Reviews.Author: gtucker7848
Reviews.Content: Disclosures: I have owned every Kindle product from the first generation E-reader. Additionally, I have owned and temporarily used an IPad, an Asus Transformer tablet, and a Samsung Galaxy Note tablet. I currently use, and very much enjoy, a Motorola Xoom tablet (second generation). With all that said, here are my thoughts on the Kindle Fire 8.9" tablet (16g, without special offers, no LTE).Pros: My first impression upon holding the tablet is that it is extremely thin and light. The footprint size is almost identical to an android based 10.1" tablet, however the screen size of the Kindle Fire is only 8.9". This creates a very large bezel around the Kindle Fire, but the trade off is that the Fire is much thinner (only half the thickness of my Xoom tablet) and therefor much lighter. The rest of the hardware is limited and strait forward. A USB charging port, a volume rocker (nice upgrade from the first generation) and a small and somewhat hard to locate power button. Many reviews complain about the power button, but I rather like it. the fact that it is small and somewhat stiff means that it is not easily triggered by accident. Additionally, there is a utility grade front facing camera (meant to be used as a web cam for skype, which is pre-loaded on this tablet), as well as dual dolby speakers on the back of the device. The speakers are absolutely the best I have ever heard on any tablet, bar none.The software remains geared towards Amazon content consumption, with several very nice upgrades from the first generation model. First, the menu options have been expanded, and now include audiobooks, games, photos, and shop. As always, all content is stored for free in the cloud if you pay for prime membership (only $80/year). The on board productivity apps, including email, calendar, and contacts, sync seamlessly with all your active accounts, including Google, Microsoft, Yahoo, Outlook,Twitter, Facebook, etc. The overall user interface is basically the same, with a couple of nice additions. First, the favorites section is no longer a book shelve format, instead being accessed by a star icon available at all times. The navigation tools are always available with a swipe from the right bezel, and the settings and notifications bar are always available with a swipe from the top bezel. One very nice addition is in the music application. You can now leave your music or playlist on all the time, and control it through the notification bar. This is a very quick and easy way to control your background music. The newsstand application is simply amazing, as usual, and makes similar offerings from Apple and Google seem pedestrian and silly. Additionally, Amazon has included more settings within the books application (such as different font styles and background options) which make this tablet very functional as a e-book reader as well. The whisper sync and Xray options are as advertised and basically still in development mode, with only a limited amount of content currently being able to take advantage of them.Cons: The main user interface, basically a giant carousel, is really out dated. With the menu options available across the top of the device, and the favorites icon easily accessible, Amazon really should come up with some home screen widget options for this caliber of tablet. Additionally, the battery life on this tablet is average at best, and it takes a ridiculously long time to charge. From 10% battery life remaining, it takes a full 4-5 hours to receive a full charge, and this is using the fast charging adapter (sold separately?!?!). My Xoom tablet has better battery life, and fully charges in less than an hour.Overall: First, let me take a moment to comment on some of the product reviews I have read for the Kindle Fire 8.9" tablet. You not knowing how to use the device, or not fully researching the specifications of the device, does not make this an inferior device. Additionally, you having an outdated wireless internet connection does not make this a slow device. And finally, not having access to 800,000 apps (think about that for a second), does not make this a useless device. YOU GUYS KNOW WHO YOU ARE!!!This product is completely as advertised. If you use Amazon prime, or have a content collection through Amazon already, this is an absolutely great tablet. Within five minutes of unboxing the device, you will be set up and ready to go. The apps that are available will likely include everything you already use from an independent developer. Netflix, Hulu, Snag, Pandora, Pulse, Flipboard, HBO go, News Republic, Tune in radio, Evernote, its all here. If you have purchase your content through Apple or Google, why are you even reading this, this tablet is not for you. Additionally, if you need a tablet for heavy work related productivity requirements, this is not your device. You need to be reading the product reviews for a Windows 8 device instead. If you want to watch movies and TV shows, listen to music, read books and magazines, check your emails, browse the web (including Google's mobile website and Youtube videos, which are supported), skype with friends and family, browse and share your photos, and play some fruit ninja, then this is as good a tablet as you will find in today's market. Throw in the $300 price tag, and the unmatched free content offerings available through Amazon Prime, and its a no brainer!Finally, I am very familiar with Amazon tablets. If you're considering buying one, but have some questions I'd be happy to offer whatever help I can. I monitor comments and questions to this post through my email, so feel free to ask away.
Reviews.Title: Huge improvement from first generation...with a couple of minor issues.

Reviews.Author: Geoffrey A. Snyder
Reviews.Content: I have my new kindle and I played with it all weekend to rather mixed opinions on it.  I've had 6 kindle devices since the initial K1 and this is by far the most versatile.  As far as Amazon content goes, it works very well with them and has pretty good user interfaces to search that content.Here are some of my initial thoughts on the device:PROS* The fonts and covers on books are incredibly sharp.  The book library and store interfaces aren't much different from the one on the original Fire - it just has a much better resolution.* In streaming video, it's much easier to flip back and forth between Prime and regular movies without having to backtrack first.* It weighs about the same as the original Fire but it's much larger so it's thinner with the weight distributed across a larger area.* It has a camera - even though I would have preferred a back facing one - that works well for video conferencing.CONS* Silk still opens duplicate tabs when restarting the browser and it continues to crash at times so to that degree it's the same as that on the original Fire.  It seems to work better on pages with numerous updates like Google+ but it still needs a bit more work so it feels similar to a desktop experience.* Silk takes an extra tap now to get to bookmarks.* The original Fire had a wood grain background - this one is just black - there is just the carousel against a blank background.  The wood grain would be appreciated (if one can't choose from a set of backgrounds) to make the device seem more visually interesting when on the home screen.* They've increased the number of places where they advertise to you.  I'm dissatisfied that I have to pay extra to turn off 'special offers' while also having to turn off the 'also bought' feature on the carousel.  These are both correctable but I dislike that the application defaults to advertising to me.* I've had some trouble with my Fire waking itself up after I put it to sleep - and with it turning itself back on after I power it down.  Customer service says these are known bugs so hopefully that will go away with the next software release.Overall, it serves my primary purpose for it - book reading - well.  That's my first use for the device and the most important one.  My second use is as a web browser which it does less well.  So, I like it but with some misgivings .... I would prefer more customization but that has never been high on Amazon's priority list for any of it's kindle devices.
Reviews.Title: Fire HD 8.9" - First Impressions

Reviews.Author: D. Earls
Reviews.Content: This is my fifth Kindle, starting with the first generation e-ink reader and coming now to the 8.9" HD Fire. Easy to say - you don't get to five without liking the product.Worth the $15 to lose the Special Offers start-up screen, but in their own way the specials appearing below the carousel are impressive - they're dependent on which carousel item is in the main spot. I'm sure I'll tire of them, and my prediction is that there will be a way to get rid of them in the near future - anybody else remember how awful the first-generation carousel was at initial launch?Obviously, Amazon is using this device to encourage shopping, but after opening my first book on this device and seeing it rendered so well, I was sold. I have a background in typography, and this device set the type perfectly. When type is set perfectly, it's easy to read and all you have to concentrate on is the book.The double Wi-Fi antennas make this faster than any other Wi-Fi device in my household. Kudos for that idea. Sound is good, this version has Bluetooth and so I can use my already-owned Bluetooth speakers. All my Amazon content showed up as available for download, and in my case that's nearly a hundred books.Screen graphics are great - colors are rich and details well rendered. A step up from the first generation Kindle Fire.HUGE improvement in battery life. First generation was a battery hog; this one is WAY better. I've ordered one of the faster rechargers for it, so there will be a lot less recharging needs. The Amazon case is a great addition. It protects and shuts the screen off as you close it. Then it opens the screen back up when you open it.I'm very happy a week in, and my first generation Fire improved over the year as more apps were released for it and older apps updated. I remain an Amazon fan, and just haven't found anything these people don't do REALLY well.
Reviews.Title: From an Amazon fan

Reviews.Author: Caseyb7
Reviews.Content: I bought both to see if I could get my elderly parents to use either.I sat on the couch with them at Thanksgiving and we played with both size screens.  Even for simple reading the 7" didn't get them engaged and changing the font size didn't help.The 8.9 inch screen made a WORLD OF DIFFERENCE as I was able to engage them with reading, games, web searches and the like.So, it may be intuitive to everyone that the larger screen is better, especially for those not of current technology - but for me it was the difference between getting them to engage and not.  They already had a desktop up the stairs and I had installed a router to give them wireless.  I wanted something for them to use downstairs such that the stairs would be less of a barrier.This looks to fit the bill.Also, the camera will be something I engage too although I haven't yet.  Having the camera and Skype on the new version should be a plus and I intend to use that as they are 1000 miles away.So - if you are trying to do long distance relationships with older folks - the 8.9" screen makes a huge difference.Good luck.
Reviews.Title: 8.9 inch screen vs. 7" for gifts to seniors

Reviews.Author: Dlee "Dlee"
Reviews.Content: Ohmy,  I certainly do like this beautiful new Kindle Fire 8.9" tablet that was delivered this morning.  On the top of my Kindle is my name and next to it the words are "4th Kindle".  I liked the Kindle from the onset and they just keep getting better and better.There is no reason to go over the features because several others here have done an excellent job of that.  I will simply tell you that there is not much to criticize with this product.  Amazon has really done a great job and at a great price.  I am in a position to help others who are confused with computers or tablets.  I've spent time with many of  the other brands but, I will state loud and clear that I love this Kindle compared to many others.I did read the negative reviews here and some if not all made me chuckle.  No, there is no instruction booklet to read, it is all on the Kindle itself and it is not difficult to find.  The negative reviews made me wonder if any research or product reading was done before they ordered their Kindles.  The objections and dislikes I saw are all a matter of using the Kindle or going online and looking for the answers.  The Kindle forum here on Amazon is a wonderful place to visit and get help or good advice.Five stars plus is my vote.  If I had a wish for just one thing it would be to have a little mark on the screen where the on/off button is.  I agree it's not easy to find even though it is dead middle of the case but very imbedded.  I never turn my other Kindles off by mistake but I did manage to do it twice with this one.  Perhaps when my case/cover arrives that will be put to rest.  Heck, maybe that's what Amazon had in mind?  Most of the new covers turn the Kindle on and off automatically.  Problem solved!!Don't hesitate to order this one - it was worth the wait
Reviews.Title: Kudu's  to Amazon for a great Kindle

Reviews.Author: Dave Lu
Reviews.Content: If you are a Amazon Prime member, then you need to get this tablet.  Excellent screen, Dolby stereo sound that is second to none. Perfect size for reading. And the price!  You get so much more for your money than an Ipad!  Once you install google market on this, the apps are endless.  A lot of people complain of the limitations of this tablet, like the limited app store.  But there are workarounds that will open up the potential for this tablet.  For example, after installing google play market on this, I've got all my google apps (gmail, maps, google+, youtube), and numerous other apps running on this bad boy.  In researching for a tablet, I was looking at many different tablets including all the android tablets (7inch and 10 inch).  I ultimately decided on the 8.9 because of its perfect size for reading, in particular books, textbooks, and medical journal articles.  Highly recommend this tablet if you like to read and use Amazon services.Update: I just wanted to address some of the common complaints I see in other reviews.1. Lack of Flash Player: News flash! ALL ICS android devices do not support Flash.  It has essentially been discontinued by Adobe. Ipad never had flash. If you want Flash, install Dolphin Browser and the Flash apk.2. Lack of Android Apps:  You have two options here.  1. Sideload the Apps: Just install whatever app you want from apk file (don't have to root)  or  2. Google Play market: If you want access to all the Android apps, then you need to install the Google Play Market. It may be possible without rooting it but I haven't tried it myself (I rooted mines).3. Ads - they just appear on your lockscreen and no where else. It's not a big deal.4. No AC charger - You can use any of your micro-USB AC chargers from your other devices (ie tablets, phones).  It's a standard universal micro-usb charging port. If you don't have any, they are cheap and only a few bucks to buy.Final words:  If you want an ipad, just buy an Ipad! This is first and foremost an E-reader tablet, that is meant to be used in Amazon's ecosystem.  This is a great deal at $299 ($200 less than the cheapest Ipad 4) and with some workarounds, you can turn this into a full-blown tablet that can rival any Ipad experience.
Reviews.Title: Excellent!

Reviews.Author: Shawn W
Reviews.Content: I purchased one at $249 during Amazon's promotion. I got it two days ago and I'm not extremely disappointed with the product and Amazon's customer service.Pros:+ Really nice screen, and it feels nice to touch. Nook HD+ has better viewing experience but Fire HD+ has much better touch experience.+ Can watch Amazon prime.+ Loud speakers+ Content viewing is supposed to be good, but my unit is super slow.Cons:+ Very slow, laggy - I will talk about this in detail later+ Speakers are rear facing so you can't watch a video in bed properly.+ Hard edges hurt my palms+ Locked Android so you need to root it and run Google apps and have full Android experience.+ Can only support one account.+ Silk browser is slow and all you are viewing will be recorded by Amazon for Ads targeting.+ Input is poor. I wish I could install other input methods in android.So let's talk about its slowness. It's slow in almost all aspects. Book reading, web browsing, Video watching, app running (e.g. flipboard). When I read a book, page flipping has 1-2 s delay. It even feels slower than my paperwhite! Web browsing is slow but I guess it's because Silk redirected your URL to Amazon server first. The most important thing is bad video experience because Amazon prime is the only reason I bought this tablet on top of my other Android tablets. I tried 3 TVs/movies, all of them froze at about 5 min into the play. It's only the graphic that is frozen. Sound is still going on.I'd imagine this is a defective device as how can a new Android device with 1.5G duo core CPU be this poor? Even Nexus 7 can do better. So I contacted Amazon for a replacement. The first one ask me to restart the device, and I told her that I had already done that. Then she asked me to factory reset, and wait for 48 hours to see!!! I'm an IT expert and I know this is bulls***. It was late at night so I didn't spend much time carrying on the chat. The second day, I called again. Amazon customer service is just pushing me around, from this department to another. They put me on hold for more than 20 minutes to transfer to amazon instant video team, can you believe that?! I got a defective device, you should just fix it for me. I have no time to help your team debugging devices.Anyway, I thought the above is my unit's problem so I'd have given it a higher rating, but according to Amazon's response, they don't think it's a defective device. Wow, if Fire HD+ is like this, it doesn't even worth $100 to me. What's use of it if you can't watch HD TV and read a book smoothly? My old Galaxy Tab 10.1 is even better than it. I'm so angry with the whole experience. Even if I bought it from Best Buy, I could get a replacement easily by telling them that I'm not satisfied. I thought Amazon is good at customer service but they just tried to push me to another team and wasted my time. So I can only return this thing.
Reviews.Title: Very slow, and bad Amazon service

Reviews.Author: MiniBob
Reviews.Content: I've read an awful lot of reviews on both the 7" and 8.9" Kindle Fire HD before and after making our purchases. Some of the negative reviews are beyond comprehension and just plain silly, but with some merit. I now own the 8.9" Fire HD and my wife has the 7" Fire HD. She finds the smaller unit a better fit for her purse, since I don't carry a purse, the larger unit is perfect for me. It also is a bit smaller than the 10" tablets and perhaps the ideal size for those wanting both an e reader and a good internet tablet. We are both extremely happy with our purchases. With my HD I have easily been able to connect with the apps I use either through the Kindle store or directly through the web. Email connection with my Comcast account took 30 seconds to activate on the Kindle. It was easy to sync with my Google calendar and IGoogle and I had no problem sending documents from my PC to the Amazon cloud. For example, I uploaded the digital manual for my new mini cooper to the Amazon Cloud and opened it up on my KIndle - easier to read and find things than on the print version. I have had absolutely no problem with wifi connection, speed has been way beyond adequate, and of course the screen is beautiful. As an e reader, pages are clear, crisp, and page changing is fast. I'm very pleased with our purchases,snd also, I appreciate the reasonable pricing on these machines.As for the criticisms posted on this review site, yes I would have liked an included charger; the lack of flash has not interfered with any of my tasks; having an external charging light would have been nice, but I will survive; my fingers very easily find the power and volume buttons; why would I want to use a 9" tablet to take photos; maybe Amazon could have included a bit more written documentation, but all you could ever want is in the Kindle itself or on the web support pages. I got rid of the "other buyers have recommended scroll" through the updated software; the other ad thing on the lock screen is on my soon to be deleted list for 15 bucks, but isn't as annoying as some people claim (except for Mickey Mouse appearing several times); delivery of both Kindles was before the expected delivery date.If you want more bells and whistles, need to have access to every app in the universe, need every device you own to be capable of taking pictures, can't live without a blinking charge light, and prefer written documentation, the Kindle Fire HD may not be for you.  As for me, I am very satisfied!
Reviews.Title: Very Satisfied! Two Kindle Fire HD's

Reviews.Author: MattIM
Reviews.Content: Full disclosure: my first tablet is an iPad. I have used this tablet everyday since I bought it 2.6 years ago. It continues to serve me very well. It is a simple, elegant, and well created device. From the very beginning, the first app I acquired was the Kindle app. I have read many books on this Kindle app. About a year and half ago, Apple and Amazon changed the terms of use and acquisition within the Kindle app. You could no longer purchase a book from the app. You had to go to Amazon.com to buy a book and it would then synch to the app. I did not have a problem with this change but it did throw an extra step into my book purchasing process. It was not enough of a bother to abandon my iPad and get the Kindle hardware.When Amazon announced this product back in September 2012. I was curious about it. It looked pretty sleek and it had the media buzz about as equal to the release of a new Apple product. I started reading about it all over the internet and @ Amazon.com. So I formulated my rationalization plan on acquiring this new device:1.  The screen had to be as good as my iPad screen.2.  It had to enable me to acquire Amazon product easily-->very interested in Amazon Prime.3.  It would be a back up device for my other tablet with cellular access when wifi not available.I ordered the Kindle Fire HD (KFHD) 8.9 4G/32gig tablet on October 26, 2012 and it was delivered on 11/29/2012, one day earlier than Amazon advised. The KFHD arrived by US POST! But it started somewhere in the USA handled by FedEx. The packaging was superb. Too bad you had to rip the package to get into the device, as it makes a beautiful box otherwise.The KFHD had enough power to launch BUT during the set up process, it does advise you to plug it in. **When I ordered this device, I was warned that it did not come with a charger. I don't know how people miss that advise. In Amazon's way, it tells you that people who purchase this item also bought a charger, screen protector, and a cover/case. I'm glad that a charger was not included. I have three chargers for my iPad and I can use these chargers to plug in the KFHD's cable. Good idea Amazon-->one less device to throw away or store somewhere.The set up process was really easy. The KFHD already recognized me!! And it stepped me through the process of connecting to my home WiFi. Right after that process completed, the KFHD stepped me through the process of signing up for the 250MG/12 month introductory 4GLTE AT&T; cellular data.  ***A lot of negative comments about this cellular data is unwarranted, IMHO. AT&T; is a reputable company, the set up process to access their network was very simple. Why people had problems filling out what is in essence an application form that consisted of Name, Address/City/State/Zipcode, email address and credit card is beyond me.I am speculating that since AT&T; has been the cellular provider in past iterations of the Kindle, adding other cellular data providers would probably require hardware changes as well. For example, AT&T; and Verizon do not use the same cellular technology. Giving a poor review to the KFHD because you cannot choose your cellular data provider is like going to a bread store and demanding to buy meat. For you iPad owners, we now have a choice of buying a branded AT&T; or Verizon or Sprint iPads. Amazon would need to do the same if they were inclined to spend time to negotiate similar deals with other providers.Now, onto the device itself. The screen resolution is really good. It almost compares to the Retina screen on the iPad (3/4th generation). I can see a difference between the KFHD screen and the iPad but if I didn't have the ability to compare it would be very difficult. The KFHD's home page is easy to navigate and to scroll through every thing I have accessed on it. I have to double tap on my iPad to do the same thing. I like having my iPad apps in folders, but I can grow to like the simplicity of the KFHD's presentation.I am a little bit puzzled about aquiring apps outside of Amazon. Apparently you have to go into settings to enable this function. And then you have to go to Google+ Play to get other apps not in the Amazon app store.Amazon's browser is different. You can access other websites but the speed of acquiring those websites seems a lot slower. But faster on the KFHD than an iPad. If you want to go backwards on the screen you are reading, the back button is on the side and not embedded in the window.There is a star icon that if you press it, gives you a list of favorite apps that you can launch without going to the home screen.The sound is certainly a lot richer than the monotone iPad. I watched a 15 minute segment of a movie on the KFHD, picture and sound was very realistic. I can get the same sense on my iPad but I have to plug in earphones to the iPad.The KFHD form factor, its size and weight, is easier to hold over a longer period of time than doing the same function on my iPad.In summary, the KFHD is a very good device to acquire and use Amazon Kindle products. It is certainly a lot more reasonably priced than comparable iPad products. The 4G cellular data is a bargain compared to the the US$14.95 250 mg per month AT&T; subscription on the iPad. I hope this 'introductory offer' will continue for as long as I own this device. The screen and stereo sound are attractive. I highly recommend it to anyone who wants a tablet to read books, watch TV/Movies, and browse websites. This has met all my requirements. I cannot rate it a five star device because there is no technology available that would merit such praise. This KFHD comes close.
Reviews.Title: Great Device To Access Amazon Products

Reviews.Author: vergilius
Reviews.Content: This is my opinion of my Kindle Fire HD 8.9" 4G LTE tablet. I'm not really qualified to write a review.Love:*The display. Great HD.*The sound (I can hear the string basses at the beginning of "Das Reingold.")*The ease of navigating the Amazon world. I have Amazon Prime, which makes this device treat you like a friend. Yes, Amazon, you have made it very easy to buy stuff from you. Thank you. I'd do it anyway. If you don't have Prime, either get it or consider a Google Nexus 7 or 10 instead.*GPS and 4g. 4G is why I got this instead of a Nexus 10. ATT 4G works well here in Monroe, Michigan. GPS means that Google Maps and Back Country Navigator also work well.*The speed. It's fast.Like:*I can side load most of my apps from the Google market (but not all, unfortunately). Yeah, Google is a competitor with Amazon, so I get why I have to load them that way. It's just a bit irritating.*The battery life. Pretty good.Don't care:*Only has a front camera. Tablets are way too bulky for taking pictures. I'll just take them with my Droid Bionic and send them to my tablet for viewing and processing.Hate:The carousel. Lose it Amazon. It's extraordinarily irritating, sort of like having a cowlick in my hair that will never stay down. I want to customize a number of home screens, like my wife does on her Galaxy Tab 7.What to know:It's basically a Kindle. You know how you said when you got your first Kindle, "Gee, this is neat. Wouldn't it be great if they did it in color and you could watch videos, too?" Well, that's what Amazon has done in a superb manner.OK. Here's an update that I have to post:IF YOU USE FACEBOOK A LOT, DON'T GET A KINDLE FIRE HD. There is a major issue which at this time seems unresolved.  The Kindle Fire HD will only allow a few recent news feeds to be displayed (like maybe 15 to 20).  The last few will be displayed shaded in blue and you can't load any more of them.  So if you want to scroll down to something that you saw an hour or so ago, forget it.  The only work around that I found was to change the user agent to "desktop" instead of "android" in settings, but that makes some posts with pictures too big to view. One suggestion from an Amazon moderator on the Kindle Fire User's Forum was for us users to contact Facebook and make them aware of the problem.  It seems to me that Amazon ought to be the one to take such an initiative, since it is Amazon's modification of the Android platform that has probably caused the problem.UPDATE OF UPDATE (2/2012): The Facebook issue is resolved in the both the Facebook App and the Facebook site within Dolphin Browser on my Kindle HD.  I'm not sure who took care of the problem, but thanks!
Reviews.Title: Love most of it; dislike a couple of things

Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer "Tech is Good!"
Reviews.Content: Ok, my wife has an Ipad2, I have a Kindle Touch and a Kindle Fire(original)..so I think I can make good comparisons.  You just want to read?  Get the Kindle Paperwhite...it is like the Kindle Touch only even better(my daughter has the PaperWhite).  Can't beat the plain e-ink Kindles for just reading. I will not be giving up my trusty Kindle Touch for when I only need a reader.But for multiple uses?? Ok, the new Kindle 8.9 has me impressed!  The older plain Fire was just fine for light reading,checking email, and using apps(gaming).  But although adequate for those purposes, it was lousy for any serious websurfing...screen just too small (just like my cell phone works for the web, but not well).  Screen on the new Kindle 8.9..... just perfect!!  Goldilocks syndrome, not too small, not too large, just right!  Ipad2 is nice, but just a little too big and too heavy.Oh, I'm guessing it goes without saying that I'm fond of the Amazon ecosystem.  And I don't have to install that memory hog ITunes!!!Amazon has a winner here....it is nice enough that I'm writing this review on it!!In short, nice unit, after 6 hours with it, I'm very happy with my purchase.  If battery life is better than the original Fire, I'll be ecstatic!!Edit: Had the unit for several days, and am happier than ever.  Unit is faster than my Original Fire, and really almost the ideal size for using the web, email, etc.  Needs a case, which I am ordering,but otherwise size, speed, and usability are excellent.  My Ipad envy is gone. No need to spend $200 more, there just isn't that much that the Ipad can do that this can't (at least for me).  As always, Amazon Prime makes getting content ridiculously easy (maybe too easy sometimes!)
Reviews.Title: A short review

Reviews.Author: Shu
Reviews.Content: please make every poster click an agreement that..-they understand that Adobe not longer provides Flash for mobile devices which means the Kindle Fire HD's does not have Flash.-that the unit does not come with a charger as clearly stated in the product description.-that they understand that the unit doesn't come with a printed user guide.-if they have a problem connecting to their WiFi network or getting slow response downing loading, youtube, etc.. it's the network not the  device.-that they actually have read the production description before complaining about what the product won't do.-forgot, they should actually own and have used the device and not complain about why they didn't buy it.-if the box was crushed, dirty, etc..  they have a shipper problem not a Amazon/device problem.######################my background..-62, retired, 40 years if IT background. mainframe sna networking, tcpip networking via about every switch Cisco has ever made, last 5 or 6 years spent specializing in Cisco wireless networking.my review of the product.-arrived Monday, properly packaged, already registered to me with about 50% battery charge.-never owned a tablet or android device before but seemed fairly easy to get setup.-I downloaded and install Flash and Dolphin from watching Mr Gadget on youtube, might have taken 5 minutes.-no problems with multiple forums, youtube, pandora, nbc, cbs, pbs, usatoday, drudge, etc.. Gmail took under 5 minutes to setup.-the BT streams directly to my hearing aid streamer which streams directly into my hearing aids in stereo. the BT turns on and off automatically when going to youtube or pandora, etc.-I have added an app for WiFi and Battery.-downloaded sample books.-uploaded music to the cloud and pulled it back down to the kindle.-I have streamed several movies via the kindle to my 55 inch Samsung TV.-I can find absolutely nothing that doesn't work as designed on the kindle or works slowly.- upgrading the product to 5 stars as I can find no reason not to.btw, I ordered the charger and a stylus (which works better than my fat fingers) both were the the box with the Kindle.
Reviews.Title: Amazon..  please, please, please

Reviews.Author: Nancy Parker "N. Parker"
Reviews.Content: This won't be a fact-filled review listing all the capabilities of the Kindle Fire HD 8.9". Many have done that already extremely well.  This is purely subjective, expressing my appreciation for wonderful technology.I am completely familiar with the Fire HD, having purchased the 7” when it first launched.  I returned it because it was just too small.  I know millions love that small form factor ... not me.THIS one is perfection.  Not enough hyperboles to express how gorgeous the display is, how full and rich the sound, how smoothly movies play, how wonderful reading a book is, and most importantly for me, how perfect the size is.  It is so thin and light and is a delight to hold.  Even the carousel, which I really don't like, seems better on the 8.9" :).  It will be perfect to take in my purse!I truly love this device and that is coming from an iPad 3 owner.  Highly highly recommend!
Reviews.Title: A thing of beauty is a joy forever!

Reviews.Author: js
Reviews.Content: I love reading all these initial reviews, some are quite humorous, some are WAY too long. Mine to the point.First all the people complaining about an instruction manual, we live in a digital age... look under help menu. This tablet is not that complicated.Next, no charger included.. ok yea they could have included a charger... but wait for it... wait for it... if you are an iphone user, simply unplug the usb iphone charger and put in place the kindle usb cord and plug it in.. problem solved.Next problem... no adobe flash... here's a news flash.. not amazon's fault.. try writing adobe as they are the ones that said no more adobe flash on android products.Next... It is not a computer, or a laptop... don't expect it to be.Ok, i have only seen 2 valid, you can't get around complaints as of November 16th, no zagg skin to fit the 8.9, nor no otterbox or gumdrop case for those that prefer the heavy duty case... that should have been available when the 8.9 was released... but it probably will in the future. Go to Best Buy, get a 9"zagg and it will fit, not great, but it will do for now until zagg comes out with one.To sum it up I love it!, its cheaper than Ipad, touchscreen is nice, power button being located next to the volume button is nice.
Reviews.Title: Love it!

Reviews.Author: DonnaMae
Reviews.Content: Kindle Fire HD 8.9", Dolby Audio, Dual-Band Wi-Fi, 32 GB - Includes Special OffersI received my Fire about 2 weeks ago, as a elderly lady, and not very computer savvy, I was expecting lots of problems getting it up and running, Within 5 minutes its was going through its paces.its everything I had hoped for and more. If I can navigate through the books and buy some, set up Skype, my email account, and zip around the net, anybody should be able to do this!Some of these reviews borrow on downright stupid, and its now fair to even have to post them and bring the rating of the Kindle Fire down! Is it really perfect??? No, but what is in this world now?? I'm hoping for many fun years with this product.
Reviews.Title: Whats Wrong With These People?

Reviews.Author: Shalandra Sharma
Reviews.Content: First thing first, i think you need to have alittle bit of technical background to get the most out of this. The main reason for that is that Google play app store is not accessible on it and the Amazon app store is just not that good at this point in time as it does not have all the apps. Thus you need to know how to access other app stores like getjar etc. It will also help if you know how to sideload apps.There are a lot of articles on the net which provides you tips and tricks to get most out of this great device. I would recommend the following apps.1. An app like es file share that lets you explore the contents of your kindle. This will help you to find the apps which you can download from other app does our forums. Once you download the apps using ess file share you can find the downloaded apk file and install the app.2. Dolphin or chrome browser. I am not impressed with silk and find dolphin to be a better choice. Chrome is my second choice as it syncs all my activities from other devices but to install chrome and other google apps you will have to a little bit of research.there is a post on xda developers forum which provides step by step instructions to install google apps without rooting your kindle.3. Google apps. As i said in the point above kindle does not come pre installed with Google apps, so you will have to download them using the instructions on the net. The email client that comes puree installed sucks big time with gmail. For me it will stop syncing and i will have to remove and re add my account. Also it does not had a lot of other features provided by google gmail app.I will also advise a user guide like the one by Shelby Johnson. It has step by step instructions to get the most out of your kindle.It might sound like you have to go through a lot of hoops to get all your favorite stuff on it, but that actually is a plus point for me as it shows me the power of open source world (again different people will have different opinion about that but that's my personal opinion) and i can choose what apps i want and which ones i don't and i can get the apps from multiple sources rather being tied to just one.I will also recommend Adobe reader app over the default pdf reader. It's a free app and provides great features for your personal pdf files.Of course the default book, video and music apps for the content downloaded from Amazon app store are great.So in a nut shell the hardware on this tablet is great while the pre-installed software is so so. But the deficiencies of the software can be easily rectified using the other available alternatives. I like it and will recommend to others.
Reviews.Title: A good tablet but you need to know some tricks to get most out of it

Reviews.Author: C. Northcutt
Reviews.Content: I wanted an item that could do 5 things.1. Read textbook/published papers in PDF format2. Fast internet browsing3. Syncs well with Amazon Prime and Amazon services4. Has a high resolution screen5. Allows sideload installation of APKs (Google Android applications).I bought the Kindle Fire HD 8.9" because it is the only tablet on the market that does all 5 of these things VERY well for less than $500. After using the product, I have tried all 5 of my needs and have been impressed with the performance in all five categories.Most consumers don't stop and think what they actually want from a product - they just buy whatever has the best specifications (best screen, Gorilla glass, largest memory, fastest processor, blah blah blah...) This is not the smart way to be a consumer. If you want an apple, you don't need to buy an apple orchard. The Kindle is a product aimed at a specific set of use cases. If you are someone who likes reading, reads textbooks in PDF format, likes ridiculously fast web browsing, and wishes to sideload APKs, this is the item for you. If you want something smaller than 9 inches (not useful for reading PDFs), or something that has widgets and the Anrdoid interface, or something that has cloud storage that isn't amazon products, or something that is clearly stated in the product description as not being a service that Kindle Fire provides... then don't buy it.If everyone who bought kindle, read everything in the description and bought the product based on what it does well, this item would have no less than 5 stars. Every Android application can be installed on the Amazon Kindle without the Google Play Marketplace by simply directly downloading the APK and installing it.If you want an item for these five things, there is absolutely no better product on the market. I can't believe how lucky I was to find something that perfectly suits my consumer needs. I'm sure Kindle Fire HD "8.9 does other things well, but I don't care about them. I wanted a product that fulfilled this set of 5 criteria, and this product has been AS ADVERTISED and BETTER.
Reviews.Title: Perfect item if you know what you want

Reviews.Author: D. Hastur
Reviews.Content: I really liked the first generation Kindle Fire, but I love the Kindle Fire HD 8.9" even more.Pros:the addition of volume buttons; the addition of and HDMI output jack; more memory; higher resolution screen; faster processor; dual-band wi-fi; Dolby audio; the ON/OFF button, the volume buttons, and the line out jack (head phone jack) are not on the same side as the power and HDMI jacks (which should make a media dock possible); and more.Cons:I would still like to see Amazon add an SD Card slot or the ability to access external storage (thumb drive, etc.) by the way of an OTG cable.The 8.9" screen is a great size; not as bulky as the 10" or larger tablets, but better suited for browsing the internet, reading emails, viewing photos and videos, than the smaller tablets.I have, and will continue, to recommend this Kindle Fire.
Reviews.Title: GREAT TABLET!

Reviews.Author: Conrad P. Weller "Multi-tasker"
Reviews.Content: The Kindle Fire HD 8.9" 4G does everything it's been advertised to do, and it does it well.  The images on the screen are crisp and detailed, and the sound is gorgeous, even without earphones.  You can play an MP3-recorded  Bruckner symphony on it, without earphones, and get a very decent rendition (with earphones you'd think you're smack in the concert hall).  The Silk engine is quick and reliable, so going online is a cinch.  As a reader, it has resolved the problem of reading Tables on the Kindle, not only because text is easily readable, even if small, as a result of the bright background and the high resolution, but also because the Fire HD has a feature that allows you to focus on a Table section and enlarge it by tapping.When I first got my device, in late November of 2012, I had problems receiving email from a non-preinstalled provider (Earthlink in my case) but the problem was resoved around Christmastime with the latest software update (version 8.1.4) and, since then, I've had no problem receiving email from Earthlink (Hotmail and Yahoo have never been a problem).  Incidentally, the very annoying deficiency that plagues the first-generation Kindle Fire, and even the Kindle Fire II (non-HD), i.e., the inability to target a text search, has been resolved in both the 7" and the 8.9" Kindle Fire HD.So, the device truly delivers.  Amazon, on the other hand, is still behind with some issues.  For instance, the Kindle Fire HD can't yet install or read reference works, such as dictionaries, which are readily available on other Kindle readers, such as the Kindle Touch or the Kindle Paperwhite.  This limitation unfortunately robs the Kindle Fire HD of the bragging right to being  a "work and play" gadget.  But not everything is lost.  The Kindle Fire HD has a nice feature that allows you to both listen to and at the same time read an audio book.Though I still depend on my Kindle Paperwhite (or my beloved Kindle Touch) for some specific consultation functions, I have found the Kindle Fire HD to be a superior mobile device for enjoying almost everything that Amazon provides in the way of consumer content.  Even por those consultative functions that are still only available on other Kindle readers, I can still rely on the Silk engine and, a bit less efficiently, connect to Wikipedia or to other online sites and get my questions resolved. Since mine is a 4G-capable device, the online option is always available (though expensive) anywhere, WiFi or no WiFi.Finally, I'd like to emphasize that, as a machine, the Kindle Fire HD 8.9" 4G is beautifully compact and streamlined.  Though larger than any other Kindle, it is still easily portable, and its more ample screen offers many advantages.  I have the magnetized cover, which allows you to sart the device or to put it to sleep by just opening or closing the lid, and this feature (also available for the Kindle Paperwhite) makes everything quick and easy.For the above reasons, the Kindle Fire HD 8.9" 4G deserves an unqualified thumbs up.  Get it and enjoy it!  By the way, I believe that the 64 gigabyte option is worth the extra $100 but that the Special Offers may prove distracting (so, I parted with $15 and had them removed).
Reviews.Title: The Kindle Fire HD 8.9" 4G Certainly Delivers And Some

Reviews.Author: Ben
Reviews.Content: I will start off by saying we have an iPad2 at home and have been iPhone users since day one, I was very skeptical about buying something not only Android but modified Android at that. I am a 911 Dispatcher working 12hr shifts and was looking for something I could use to read on as well as play some basic games and surf the web, knowing this I could not justify the cost of another iPad.Controversy:I read hundreds of reviews prior to buying this device and saw the same thing over and over so I will address them here1.) No Charger!!! I read this and knew it, considering I have 4 iPhone and 2 original Kindle chargers this was 100% a non-issue for me and anyone who reads the description would know this is the case.2.) No Flash! Sorry to inform but Flash is no longer supported on mobile devices as it is basically on its way out, you can't get mad at the Kindle because the sites you visit haven't been updated.3.) Ad's! The lock screen ad doesn't bother me at all, the much complained about recomendations can be turned off the in the software and are gone.Display:Fantastic! The screen is so crisp and great I love it!Operating System:I would prefer a more open version of Android but the Amazon OS has been very stable and quick with -0- issues since unboxing, is it 100% as smooth as the iPad-no it isn't but it is very close and for the price difference it is a non-issueContent:As always Amazon content is awesome, I have subscribed to a few magazines and they work great on the larger screen, I have not gotten Prime yet but plan to soon.Apps:I read alot fo complaints about the lack of apps, I found there were so many I didn't know what to get and I suspect as more and more Fires are sold more developers will port over existing games and apps.Summary:If you want an iPad, get an iPad-you aren't going to buy one for less than $300 and for less than $300 you aren't going to get 100% of the capability-I am sorry but that is how it is, if you need a device like I did for web surfing, reading, games and nothing really heavy or involved then get the Fire, I don't think anyone who knows going into it what they are buying can complain about it!
Reviews.Title: Great Device For The Money!!

Reviews.Author: R. C. Lindner "I am here, yet I am gone"
Reviews.Content: I have bought myself an early Christmas present to replace my Google Nexus 7 tabletthat was stolen from me in Spain.I chose the Kindle Fire HD 8.9"...which was a strange choice.  The Google  Nexus 10 was preferredbut the price was much higher.Kindle Fire HD Pros:1) Screen size and resolution....does a genuine screen 12:9 1080p HD resolution.2) Sound...stereo Dolby....sounds great thru Noise-cancelling headphones3) Fastest wifi with great range...I can watch HD movies from everywhere in the house.4) Cheapest price...reduced right down to compete with Apple, but make revenue from content.5) Amazon Prime gives access to all of Amazon content, including movies (like TinTin in HD) and free Amazon 2day shipping.6) HDMI out so you can watch/listen on the TV. I bought a 15' micro HDMI cable for <$10 and an HDMI splitter to expand my hdmi in's from 2 to 3+Cons:1) Size  ....I think the 7" is the best tablet size, but need the hi res. 10" is too large to fit in a pocket.2) No GPS or Maps3) No Voice to Text ...(speech recognition) . Nexus and the iPad are excellent for this4) Screen and case are hard to keep smudge-free....there is some special coating on the glass that shows fingerprints.5) Amazon runs a modified O/S, not the Android JellyBean.  It's less of a computer, and more of a viewer.6) No rear-facing cameraI got the 16gb WI-fi version, not the (more expensive) 4G.Its a great value...It is nice to watch 'TV' without commercials..
Reviews.Title: EARLY CHRISTMAS PRESENT FOR THOSE WHO ARE NAUGHTY

Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: I received my Kindle 4 days ago and I love it! I was surprised to receive it way ahead of schdule but I have enjoyed learning the features on it since it arrived. The only issue (if you could call it an issue) that I had was that there was no quick start guide in the box but with just a little effort I located the instructions on the Amazon website. The size is just right and it is not too heavy to hold comfortably in your hands. I like the option the change the page color for books to sepia and this has made it very easy on my eyes for reading. I like the option of being able to see what you have downloaded on the device as well as what is on your cloud. The variety of apps for the kindle is very good and they are always adding more. Since I have amazon prime I am able to view a lot of movies and shows for free. The quality of the video is excellent! The location of the power button is the only thing that I am not really fond of although it really isn't a major drawback. It is very easy to accidentally push it and have the kindle go into the "sleep" mode. I just have to be careful where I am holding the kindle and hopefully this will no longer an issue at all after I receive my cover. I still need to put a screen protector on it and will do that soon. I would DEFINITELY order this again and have told several friends about the new kindle already.
Reviews.Title: Great Kindle!

Reviews.Author: this_moment
Reviews.Content: I'll make this short and sweet, since there are some great, very detailed reviews already left by others. The one thing I don't see mentioned in any other reviews that I think is critical decision-making data for anyone thinking of paying for the 4G model, is that after the first year you pay AT&T;'s normal monthly data rates. Those are currently $15/m for the same amount of data as in the first year (so now $180/yr instead of $49) or $30/m once you get into the GBs range. However, note that with other Kindle devices you get free lifetime 3G!
Reviews.Title: 4G only $49 for first year... then $180+/yr

Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer "BookEnd"
Reviews.Content: Well, I did it. I went ahead and ordered the 32 GB Kindle Fire HD 8.9". I was in sticker shock, of course, as it came out to a good $500 when I added Poetic KeyBook Bluetooth Keyboard Case for Kindle Fire HD 8.9 Black (Support Auto Sleep/Wake Function)(3 Year Manufacturer Warranty From Poetic)and the warranty and a decal (for when it's not in the case).  But what the heck, you only live once, right?  I was extremely excited to receive it, and with the Amazon Prime Student 2 day shipping, it came in the mail exactly two days later.  The sleek black box contains the Kindle, a USB cord, and nothing else- but I'm a repeat Kindle customer, so I have plenty of micro USBs lying around the house.  The quality of the micro USB charger you use does seem to make a difference however, as some of my chargers didn't work at all (though they were working on other devices just fine), while others charged pretty decently.  I would say, after having my Kindle for a couple of days now, that it is worth it to purchase the rapid charger that Amazon offers you for $9.99 when you add the Kindle to your cart.Just a word of warning...a full charge lasts me quite awhile, but I like to charge it to 100% when I do charge it, and that takes FOREVER on a regular micro USB.  When I turned it on, I was pleasantly surprised to see how the carousel was already customized with some of my favorite books. The carousel can be easily changed to what you use, read, listen to, or watch the most often.  My carousel is a mix of the email shortcut, the Amazon Silk(that's Amazon's web browsing brand, for want of a better description) shortcut, which shows a pic of my last page visited, some game apps, and my favorite books.  The carousel is very responsive, and it changes functionality depending on whether you are in landscape or portrait mode. In landscape mode( my favorite mode) you see your carousel on a black background, and a row of options across the top that are shortcuts to music, video, books, apps, etc.  In the bottom right hand corner is the star button, which allows you to look up your favorites, though those might already be on your carousel.  In portrait mode, the carousel is obviously narrower, and across the bottom, for every item on your carousel, you see "Customers Also Bought" and a row of pictorial suggestions based on those selections.  I didn't notice this when I went to look at a display of the Kindle Fire HD 8.9" at my local Best Buy.  One of the reasons I was so eager to purchase the new Kindle Fires is that I'm rough on electronics; I have accidentally damaged three kindle keyboard editions by leaving them in bad spots, where the screens were pushed on (mostly by dogs on the couch) a tad too hard, rendering them useless. The gorilla glass of the Kindle Fire is nice and sturdy- though I am glad that I purchased the 2 year warranty, just in case.  Fingerprints/smudges can be rather annoying to look at when the kindle is off and all you see are your prints marring the pristine black of the screen.  But I don't often stare at my kindle when it's in standby mode, so I don't consider it a big deal whatsoever.  But I thought I would bring it up in case that does bother other people thinking about buying this.  I was SO surprised at how fast the downloads and web browsing and toggling are on this Kindle.
